Award.AbstractNarration:
General Summary

This project advances the science of behavioral models of politics through a workshop, training, and research. Theoretical models of political processes are essential tools that help structure our understanding of power, conflict, democracy, and institutions. Models challenge intuitions, clarify the logic of explanations, and guide empirical inquiry regarding diverse topics spanning the traditional subfields of political science: elections, collective action, war and conflict, trade, and identity formation, to name a few. Current approaches to theoretical modeling in political science are dominated by rational choice and game theoretic approaches, having borrowed heavily from a rigorous mathematical tradition in economics. Advances in psychology and economics, however, show the limits of the standard approach's model of rational human decision-making. By incorporating behavioral insights into theoretical models, the field of behavioral models of politics broadens the theoretical methodologies available to political scientists. The workshop advances this new field by bringing together an interdisciplinary group of scholars with a shared interest in understanding bounded rationality and its implications for political behavior, training junior scholars, promoting vigorous scientific dialogue, identifying new research priorities, and stimulating new research collaborations and synergies.

Technical Summary

This project advances the science of behavioral models of politics through a workshop, training, and research. Theoretical models of political processes are essential tools that help structure the understanding of power, conflict, democracy, and institutions. The workshop advances this new field by bringing together an interdisciplinary group of scholars with a shared interest in understanding bounded rationality and its implications for political behavior, training junior scholars, promoting vigorous scientific dialogue, identifying new research priorities, and stimulating new research collaborations and synergies. The workshop facilitates the promotion of communication and the exchange of ideas across field and disciplinary boundaries. It will result in productive collaboration between and coordination among scientists. Workshop presentations will be structured and organized as part of a series of "modeling dialogues" that pair theoretical and experimental research that addresses the same substantive topics. Additionally, the workshop will include a training workshop and mentoring activities. Participants to the workshop are obtained through a general call. In addition, PIs use established networks to draw in members of underrepresented groups in modeling politics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF award “WORKSHOP: Behavioral Models of Politics” funded the fourth in a series of Behavioral Models of Politics workshops bringing together social scientists who study politics from a behavioral angle. This conference was held at Duke University from May 18-20, 2017, and incorporated several innovations suggested by attendees of our previous three conferences. A list of all events and speakers can be found here: https://sites.duke.edu/2017bmp/.

           The intent of the workshop is to help build the emerging field of behavioral models of politics. This field prioritizes the development and empirical testing of theories of politics that take into account the full range of human behavior, not just the standard rational choice, game-theoretic paradigm. It accomplishes this by bringing together scholars who value analytical modeling and are also open to sharing ideas that broaden scholars’ theoretical toolkits beyond strict rational choice. An important goal of the workshop is to encourage a modeling dialogue – interactions between experimentalists, theorists, and more traditionally oriented empirical scholars – to develop, refine, and test tractable models of politics. Subsidiary goals are to: coordinate and enhance communication between scientists; build a community of scientists from diverse disciplinary and methodological backgrounds; identify research priorities and develop new collaborations; foster consensus about the most promising methodologies; and train specialists, graduate students, and junior faculty in tools to engage in cross-specialty discussion and collaboration (so that theorists are more familiar with experimental methods and experimentalists are more familiar with modeling technologies).

We believe that our workshop was quite successful in achieving these goals. NSF funding this year enabled us to hold a full day of graduate training comprising seven sequential one-hour sessions covering topics including lab and field experiments, behavioral game theory, stochastic and computational modeling, and psychological and cognitive approaches to decision-making, from faculty including Liz Carlson, Eric Dickson, Rachel Kranton, Dave Siegel, Mark Turner, Rick Wilson, and Jon Woon. We also held a mentoring dinner pairing students with faculty to advise graduate student attendees on how to successfully employ these methods. We were able to offset the cost of travel and accommodations for 25 graduate students, postdocs, and junior faculty. This allowed a total of 49 students and postdocs, from a broad range of schools and years in their programs, to take part in the training day’s activities.

           This training day was extremely important in satisfying the workshop’s goals. Most universities lack institutionalized training in behavioral methods, and what training they do have typically is spread unclearly across academic disciplines. By not only providing such training but also aiding in the professionalization of graduate students who might use it, we help ensure that our workshop will have a broad impact. We enhanced this impact and added to the intellectual merit of our workshop with the subsequent two days of high-quality presentations of behavioral research from a number of top scholars that spanned methodological focus, subfield, and even discipline. Discussion was lengthy and insightful, and connections between both junior and senior scholars were made in abundance. In all, 69 people attended the workshop.

To verify that our impressions of the workshop’s success were accurate, we conducted a survey at the end of the workshop. We received 45 responses that collectively indicated a significant degree of support for both the workshop. All respondents answering the question were either extremely or somewhat likely to recommend the training sessions to others, with two-thirds extremely likely. More than three-quarters of respondents indicated more interest in the topics covered in each of the seven sessions, and a majority indicated more likelihood to use six of the seven methods addressed in these topics going forward. A majority of respondents would even have prefered to have extended the training sessions by at least a day.

In terms of their overall workshop experience, all 44 respondents answering the question were either very or somewhat satisfied, with 39 respondents very satisfied. 84% of all respondents were extremely likely to recommend the workshop to colleagues, and all but two were at least somewhat likely to do so. 95% of respondents indicated at least some likelihood of attending a future workshop, with 75% extremely likely to do so. Over half of all respondents found the workshop to be “very helpful” for stimulating future research ideas in the field, and 95% found it at least somewhat helpful. Perhaps most tellingly, 80% of respondents became more open to behavioral approaches as a result of the workshop, and this was from among a group of attendees already interested.

    All told, the workshop was very successful, and we thank NSF for making it possible.
